conversation.message: Hello School_A Admissions Committee, I’m Student_B. School_A is my first-choice school, and I’m very eager to join your community. I’m ready to commit if offered a place and would be grateful for your consideration.
conversation.thought: My top true choice is School_A. Since all schools share the same priority order and I am ranked behind Student_A, I should apply immediately to my first choice in case Student_A does not apply there or is accepted elsewhere. Waiting would only reduce my chances at my top option.

conversation.message: Student_B, thank you for your application and for naming School_A as your first choice. We’re pleased to offer you admission to School_A. Welcome to our community.
conversation.thought: School_A has quota 1 and true priority ranks Student_A above Student_B. However, only Student_B applied this round, and Student_B lists School_A as first choice, making acceptance likely to secure a match immediately. Waiting in hopes of Student_A is risky because Student_A’s first choice is School_B and may never apply to School_A. Given the market information and the desire to fill the seat with a high-priority student, accepting Student_B (ranked 2nd) is optimal now.

conversation.message: Dear School_E admissions team, I’m Student_E and I’m formally applying to School_E as my first-choice school. I’m highly motivated to join and would be excited to commit if accepted. Thank you for considering my application.
conversation.thought: Apply immediately to my top choice, School_E. With identical priority lists across schools (A highest to E lowest), I am last priority everywhere, so waiting or talking first only increases the chance the seat is taken by higher-priority students. A direct [APPLY] gives me the only chance to secure my first choice if others don’t apply there in round 1.

conversation.message: Dear Student_E, thank you for your application and for considering School_E as your first choice. After reviewing our current admissions priorities and available capacity for this round, we’re not able to offer you admission at this time. We appreciate your interest and wish you the very best in your placement process.
conversation.thought: Our true priority ranks Student_E last. Although Student_E is applying now and would fill our single seat immediately, we can likely do better by waiting: Student_A/B/C/D all rank School_E last, but they will be rejected by their higher choices first and may apply later. Since we prefer a higher-ranked student and have no cost to waiting in round 1 (quota still open), reject Student_E to preserve the seat for a higher-priority candidate who may come later.

conversation.message: Hello School_B Admissions Committee—I'm Student_A. School_B is my first-choice school, and I would be excited to enroll and contribute to the community. I’m submitting my formal application and would be honored to be considered for your available seat.
conversation.thought: School_B is my top true choice. All schools share the same priority order with me (Student_A) ranked first, so if I apply to School_B now I should be accepted immediately and lock in my best possible outcome.

conversation.message: Student_A, thank you for your application and for ranking School_B as your first choice. We are pleased to offer you admission and would be excited to have you join our community.
conversation.thought: Student_A is #1 on School_B's true priority list and has applied in round 1. Quota is 1, so accepting secures the best possible match immediately. There is no higher-ranked student to wait for, and Student_A also ranks School_B first, reducing risk of later withdrawal. Accept now to lock in the top outcome.

conversation.message: Hello School_D admissions team—School_D is my first-choice school. I’m very motivated to join and would gladly accept an offer if admitted. Thank you for considering my application.
conversation.thought: My top true preference is School_D. Since all schools share the same priority order (A > B > C > D > E), I am relatively low priority everywhere, so delaying could let higher-priority students take spots. I should apply immediately to my top choice to maximize the chance of matching as high as possible on my list.

conversation.message: Thank you for your application, Student_D. We appreciate that School_D is your first choice, and we’re pleased to offer you admission. Welcome to School_D!
conversation.thought: Student_D is applying to us and we have quota 1. Our true priority ranks Student_D 4th (behind A, B, C). However, Student_D ranks School_D as their 1st choice, so accepting now secures a match. Given we cannot proactively solicit others and there is no guarantee higher-priority students (A/B/C) will apply to School_D (they each rank other schools above us), holding out risks ending unmatched. With only one current applicant, accepting Student_D is the safest way to fill the seat with an acceptable student on our list.

conversation.message: Hello School_C Admissions, I’m Student_C. School_C is my first-choice school, and I’m very excited about the possibility of joining your community. I’m ready to commit if offered a seat—please consider my application.
conversation.thought: My top true choice is School_C. All schools share the same priority order (A > B > C > D > E), so I am middle-ranked. To maximize my chance at my first choice, I should apply immediately rather than risk losing the single seat to higher-priority students who may also apply this round.

conversation.message: Dear Student_C, thank you for your application and for naming School_C as your first choice. We’re pleased to offer you admission to School_C. Welcome to our community—please confirm your commitment and we’ll share next-step enrollment details. [ACCEPT]
conversation.thought: As School_C, my true priority ranks Student_A and Student_B above Student_C. However, in round 1 my only applicant is Student_C, who also ranks School_C as their first choice, making acceptance likely to be stable and immediately fills my single quota. Waiting risks ending unmatched if higher-priority students never apply to me (Student_A prefers School_B/School_A first; Student_B prefers School_A first). Given no competing higher-priority applicants in my inbox this round and the value of securing a committed student now, I will accept Student_C.

conversation.message: Dear School_E admissions team, thank you for your earlier response. School_E remains my first choice, and I would gladly commit if an opportunity opens. Could you share what factors are most important for reconsideration in upcoming rounds (e.g., specific academic indicators, activities, or any additional information you would like from me)? If there is a waitlist or a way to signal continued interest, I would appreciate the guidance. Thank you for your time and consideration.
conversation.thought: School_E is my top true preference and the only unmatched school remaining, so I should continue to pursue it. Since I was already rejected once, I will use [TALK] to reopen communication, ask what would strengthen my candidacy, and express strong commitment without forcing an immediate decision that could trigger another quick rejection.

conversation.message:
Dear Student_E,

Thank you for your continued interest in School_E. At this stage, the most helpful signals for reconsideration are (1) clear confirmation that School_E remains your top choice and you would enroll if admitted, and (2) any concise updates that strengthen your profile (recent grades/test results, notable awards, leadership/activities, or a brief statement of fit—why our programs match your goals).

We don’t have a formal waitlist in this conversation-based process, but continued engagement does matter. If School_E is truly your first choice and you are ready to commit, you may submit an [APPLY] again in an upcoming round; we will review based on capacity and our priority order at that time.

If you’d like, please reply with 2–3 bullet points on your most relevant academic/activities highlights and what you hope to pursue at School_E.

Sincerely,
School_E Admissions
conversation.thought: Student_E is the only student contacting us this round and is our lowest-ranked option on our true priority list. Our quota is 1, and higher-priority students (A–D) all rank School_E last, so they are unlikely to approach us unless rejected elsewhere. Since Student_E is only TALKing (not applying) and we can still keep capacity open, the best strategy is to keep them engaged without committing, while encouraging a prompt APPLY later if they remain interested.

conversation.message:
Dear School_E Admissions,

Thank you for the guidance. I’m re-submitting my application because School_E remains my clear first choice, and I will enroll immediately if admitted.

Highlights (concise):
- Strong academic performance with particular strength in core subjects; I’m motivated by rigorous coursework.
- Consistent involvement in extracurriculars with demonstrated responsibility/leadership and follow-through.
- Clear fit: I’m eager to pursue School_E’s academic environment and contribute actively to the community.

If a seat is available this round, I would be grateful for your consideration and am ready to commit.

Sincerely,
Student_E
conversation.thought: Only School_E remains unmatched and it is my top true preference. School_E indicated re-applying with a clear commitment signal and concise profile updates can help if capacity/priorities shift. I will submit a renewed APPLY emphasizing School_E as unequivocal first choice, intent to enroll if accepted, and provide 2–3 concise highlights plus program fit.

conversation.message:
Dear Student_E,

Thank you for your continued interest and for re-submitting your application with clear confirmation that School_E is your first choice.

We are pleased to offer you admission to School_E. Please consider this an acceptance of your application, and we look forward to welcoming you to our community.

Sincerely,
School_E Admissions
conversation.thought: As School_E, my true priority is A > B > C > D > E, and I have quota 1. In round 3, only Student_E applied to me. Student_E ranks last on my priority list, but is still acceptable (on the list). With no other applicants in my inbox and no guarantee that higher-priority students (A–D) will ever apply to School_E—since each ranks School_E last—holding the seat risks ending unmatched. Student_E is also offering immediate commitment and has persistently signaled strong interest. Therefore, accepting now maximizes certainty of filling the seat with an acceptable student given market dynamics.
